items.abstract: <jats:p>The structure of the title compound, [Li<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>8</jats:sub>)(H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O)<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>]·H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O, is composed of dinuclear molecules in which the ligand bridges two symmetry-related Li<jats:sup>I</jats:sup>ions, each coordinated also by two water O atoms, in an<jats:italic>O</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic>′-manner. The Li and N atoms occupy special positions on twofold rotation axes, whereas a crystal water molecule is located at the intersection of three twofold rotation axes. The Li<jats:sup>I</jats:sup>cation shows a distorted trigonal–bipyramidal coordination. Two carboxylate groups remain protonated and form short interligand hydrogen bonds. The molecules are held together by a network of hydrogen bonds in which the coordinating and solvation water molecules act as donors and carboxylate O atoms as acceptors, forming a three-dimensional architecture.</jats:p>
title: (μ-Dihydrogen pyrazine-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylato-κ6O2,N1,O6;O3,N4,O5)bis(diaqualithium) monohydrate

items.abstract: <jats:p>The title compound, {[Li(C<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>)(H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O)]·0.5H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O}<jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub>, comprises four symmetry-independent Li(C<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>)(H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O) units which form molecular ribbons running along the<jats:italic>c</jats:italic>-axis direction. Within each ribbon, the ligand molecule, acting in a μ<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>-mode, bridges two adjacent Li<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>cations using both of its<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic>-bonding sites. The coordination environment of each of the four Li<jats:sup>+</jats:sup>cations can be described alternatively as either slightly distorted trigonal–bipyramidal or slightly distorted square–pyramidal. The ribbons are interconnected by a network of O—H...O hydrogen bonds.</jats:p>

items.abstract: <jats:p>The structure of the title compound, {(N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>5</jats:sub>)[Li<jats:sub>3</jats:sub>(C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>N<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O<jats:sub>4</jats:sub>)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>(H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O)<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>]·H<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>O}<jats:sub><jats:italic>n</jats:italic></jats:sub>, is composed of molecular dimers, each built up of two symmetry-related Li<jats:sup>I</jats:sup>ions with distorted trigonal–bipyramidal coordinations bridged by two deprotonated ligand molecules<jats:italic>via</jats:italic>their<jats:italic>N</jats:italic>,<jats:italic>O</jats:italic>-bonding sites. Doubly solvated Li<jats:sup>I</jats:sup>ions with a distorted tetrahedral geometry link adjacent dimers, forming a polymer generated by bridging bidentate carboxylato O atoms to Li<jats:sup>I</jats:sup>ions in adjacent dimers, forming anionic layers parallel to the<jats:italic>ac</jats:italic>plane with monoprotonated hydrazinium cations and crystal water molecules positioned between them. The layers are held together by an extended system of hydrogen bonds in which the hydrazinium cations and coordinated and crystal water molecules act as donors and carboxylate O atoms act as acceptors.</jats:p>
title: Poly[hydrazin-1-ium [diaquabis(μ4-pyridazine-3,6-dicarboxylato)trilithate] monohydrate]
